content:
On https://backdropcms.org/upgrade-from-drupal it says:

If you are running an install profile other than the core 'standard' profile, make sure you have a Backdrop version of that profile, or switch to the standard profile in Drupal 7.

How does one 'switch' install profiles in Drupal?
And why is this necessary?

this is the how-to that I've followed in the past when I wanted to switch from a non-standard profile back to standard https://www.davehall.com.au/blog/dave/2012/09/12/switching-installation-profiles-existing-drupal-sites

for me, the reason was to move away from modules stored in the profile directory and back to a less complex setup of everything in sites/all/modules . I sorta hate installation profiles in general so I find it easier to maintain a project long term if that complexity is not in my way

Ok, considering the way to 'switch' profiles is to just make sure the new profile is enabled, then change the config value to the new one, and considering my old install profile doesn't include any modules, I'm going to assume it's safe to skip this step...
Is there anything resembling an upgrade path for panels layouts?

nvm, I found https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/3680 which doesn't have it listed as being available

[META] Add upgrade paths for modules now integrated into core 路 Issue #3680 路 backdrop/backdrop-issues
This is a meta issue to track the upgrade path for modules that have been moved into core, or integrated into existing system modules. #3687 | Admin Menu (moved into core, renamed to Admin Bar modu...
Hi Everybody. I have a question about Features.
(avoiding ranting about my hate of features and wondering if I can help)

I seem to remember someone (@jenlampton comes to mind) describing a module or technique to move functionality that had been burned into Features back into the database. But I've scoured the internet for this info and come up empty. Can anybody point me to where/how to do it?

yep, jen released an unfeatureize module, I've had success with it
looking for url
https://www.drupal.org/project/unfeaturize
Super duper awesome!
Quick 2nd question, only connected in that it's relevant to a job interview I have in 1/2 hour:
Do D7 views translate OK when you migrate to Backdrop?
I think they do as long as they're in the DB.
Great. I assumed they did to. BUT: I had assumed they would translate to D8, and was TOTALLY FLOORED to discover yesterday that they don't!
The Official Recommended process for converting views from D7 to D8 is: RECREATE THEM BY HAND!
I mean, holy cow. This is a giant competitive advantage for us.
Unfeaturize!

I just had the need to "unfeaturize" a few weeks ago and found a patch for the features module that worked pretty nicely. Didn't know about the module, didn't find it in any of my searches. Will keep that in mind.
@jenlampton ++
jenlampton 1000% (Karma: 3)
BTW, there's https://www.drupal.org/project/view_migration but no activity for a couple of years now, and still in alpha :thumbs_down:
Even if the View is in Features you can still upgrade it to Backdrop. The View is still in the db too, from my experience
Only if the view is overridden. If the feature is in a clean state, the view is not in the database.
I'm super excited by this. I think this is a major competitive advantage Backdrop has over D8, which we should document, improve, and promote.

Backdrop has at least four giant advantages over D8 when it comes to migrating from D7:
1) Themes are much easier to migrate
2) Modules are wildly easier to migrate
3) Views are easy to migrate in Backdrop and impossible to migrate in D7.
4) The author of the UnFeaturize module is on our team :)

If we could make the case that migrating from Backdrop to D8 is no harder (or perhaps even easier) than migrating from D7 to D8, I think we could generate tremendous interest.

(I'm working on something intended to make it easier to migrate from Backdrop to D8)
@Luke McCormick ++
mccormick** Props to you for all your hard work. (Karma: 1)

BWPanda said:

Here's the blog post I promised: https://packweb.eu/blog/migrating-drupal-7-backdrop-cms

@BWPanda Interesting read! In section "Upgrade" you recommend to install a vanilla Backdrop site before doing other tasks and running update.php. Any particular reason for the difference to https://backdropcms.org/upgrade-from-drupal, Step 3, which recommends to run the installer later?

@Olaf Grabienski I'm not sure I understand your question... I suggest running update.php in step 8 of the 'Upgrade' process, while b.org suggests running it in their step 7 of their 'Upgrade' process. Same same, right?
You're right, wasn't clear enough, I guess it's more the order of the "other steps", specifically when to run the installer but also other things. Let's compare...

Official docs:

  • Download Backdrop and extract the files
  • Create the database
  • DON'T run the installer
  • Copy the files directory from Drupal
  • Import the Drupal 7 database
  • Update the Backdrop settings.php file
  • RUN the installer
  • Download Backdrop contributed modules
  • Visit update.php
FTR, mine was based on @jenlampton's one, when she did a meeting about it once...

Your article:

  • Download and extract Backdrop
  • Setup a database
  • Configure 'settings.php'
  • RUN the installer
  • Download Backdrop modules
  • Delete everything in Backdrop's 'active' config directory
  • Replace 'files' directory (except 'config')
  • Replace the Backdrop database
  • Visit update.php
I see!
I'm having a site which I want to upgrade to D7. As I did it only once before (with my own site), I'm trying to wrap my head around the various instructions.

Here's Jen's ones: bit.ly/2TiW4x4

SVF Upgrade
StoneValleyFarm.com Drupal 7 to Backdrop CMS upgrade Link to this document: http://bit.ly/2TiW4x4 Backdrop CMS is a simple, lightweight, and easy-to-use Content Management System for building professional websites. Backdrop is a fork of Drupal 7. It introduces Configuration Management, adds a ...
I adapted them for my own needs obviously
Thanks! I also want to write my own notes, in my own words which I fully understand without having to think about them too much every time in the future.

Yeah, there's probably lots of different ways to do it. Ultimately, just make sure you have a full backup of everything before you start, then you can start over and try different ideas as much as you want :wink:
Yep! I guess I'll copy the D7 site first and will then upgrade the copy.
@BWPanda How do you treat the files directory? With my last upgrade, I had some issues because I just copied sites/default/files from Drupal to files in Backdrop.

The docs recommend to create a symlink then, but that's not possible on every hosting service. But I also don't like the alternative ("Place the files in the same location they were in Drupal"). Do you know of any other alternative?

My sites are all multisites (D7 and Backdrop), so I just moves files from one files dir to the other (that's why it's good to setup a blank Backdrop site first so you don't have any issues with directories, permissions, etc.)

Setup Backdrop, make sure everything works, then copy over Drupal stuff and see what (if anything) breaks. You might need to do a search & replace in the DB to change occurances of the old files path to the new one.

I can't really remember what I've done in the past. The current site I'm migrating was too hard to upgrade (it was a D6 site that was updated to D7, so there's lots of old stuff in there). I decided it's easier to setup a new Backdrop site and import content with Feeds this time.

do a search & replace in the DB

Hm, I guess, I have too less experience to do so, scared to break more things then!
Backups are your friend. I'm no good with SQL, so I just use phpMyAdmin for that.
So, Feeds was working well?

So far. Takes a lot longer though (setting up data export view in D7, setting up content type in Backdrop with appropriate fields, setting up feed importer in Backdrop, importing, debugging, writing PHP code to do the more tedious things (exploding a comma-separated list of values into a multi-valued field, etc.)
Ah, good to know! Will continue the upgrade approach then in this case. Thanks for your help!
Anytime (unless I'm asleep :wink: )

@BWPanda Another question: in the "Preparation" section of your upgrade instructions you mention "Ported" modules twice:

7 'Ported' modules: Disable, but don't uninstall, all modules in the 'Port' category. Leave them in the filesystem.
(...)
12 'Ported' modules: Delete all modules in the 'Port' category from the filesystem. Don't disable or uninstall them.

Is one of them actually the "Contrib" category?
@Olaf Grabienski You are right! 12 should be contrib.
@BWPanda What do you think: Preparing a D7 site for the upgrade to Backdrop, do I even disable, uninstall and remove Drupal core modules which are removed in Backdrop? E.g. "Overlay".
@Olaf Grabienski I think so. Otherwise there's a chance there might be cruft left over in the database, since Backdrop probably doesn't have the code to remove all that itself.
Thanks! That's what I'd assumed as well.
:thumbs_up: The less code there is to migrate, the less chance of problems :wink:
@BWPanda On your upgrades, did you also remove the D7 "Dashboard" module? Not sure because Backdrop as of 1.13 has the new Dashboard module.

Not sure, but I think so. Basically, the only reason you wouldn't uninstall something before migrating is because Backdrop needs the settings/configuration and/or you don't want data loss. In the case of a dashboard module, I don't think there's any setting to migrate, and no data to lose...
Sounds reasonable! Will try to remember this: Does Backdrop need configuration or data of the module in question?
Thanks again, @BWPanda !
